Before I start my review, allow me to mention some things:
1. I played this game from season 2, and tried to get every possible cosmetics you can obtain from the events 
2. I bought the Limbus pass from season 4, and also bought the current season Limbus pass
3. Currently, I mostly play the mirror dungeon (basically the weekly gacha currency grind), and only play luxcavation (the upgrade materials grind) when required.

So, it this game good? Well, I enjoy playing this game and attempting the challenges it presented, whether its the main story's bosses, or the "achievements" you can finish in order to get rewards/cosmetics. I also like the world-building of this game, and the characters presented in it.  Gacha-wise, this game is also very generous, with the option to buy characters whose banners are finished, with the currency you can get for free.

However, looking at the game's current state, I am not sure whether I should recommend this game for new players. In this game, the IDs (characters pullable from gacha) are divided into three tiers: the base ID you get when you start playing, two stars, and three stars. Needless to say, you are less likely to get the three stars from the gacha (even though as mentioned above, you also have the option to buy them without spending the gacha currency), and levelling up these three stars will require way more materials than the two stars. 

Seems pretty normal so far right? Well, the problem is, the current season (which started from may 2025) only dished out three stars, and even added new collaboration EGOs (the closest thing to this is the gacha-able "items" your characters use), which of course, you can only get when the collaboration is still going on. 
With no new addition of two stars, the grinding you have to do to max out (or even just to get the three stars) became heavier, therefore putting more pressure on the newer players. This is especially bad due to the fact that in order to fully utilize the power of your team, a specific combination of characters is required (or in other words, getting one "good" character is not enough). 

All in all, I love the game, and even more, the community. But the recent decisions made by the developer have been pretty shaky at best, which made me think that I (and of course, new players) should probably wait some time before deciding whether I should continue investing my money in this game or not. 

Lastly, keep in mind that this review is in the end, just a single player's review, so it may be heavily biased. I would like to hear what other player's are thinking about the game, so feel free to comment (or even just straight up criticize this comment if you think it's wrong).

I only started playing Limbus Company because my friends also played it. But let me be very clear: this is the kind of game you stumble into when you're hopeless and depressed, and it tells you a message you didn't know you needed to hear. There is (or will be) at least one Sinner whose story resonates with you on a personal level.
The overarching story and the world is very dark, but each Canto focuses on overcoming and accepting past trauma and that there are still things worth living for despite everything. The Sinners are very flawed people but you will love them anyways. It takes a bit to get going, but Canto 3 onwards is good.
[i]Heed the content warnings[/i], but I'll say I normally avoid games with graphic content yet I had no trouble with Limbus Company. Once you get past Canto 1 (which sets the tone of the world) and the Sinners get more comfortable with each other, there's enough goofy, lighthearted shenanigans to help balance out the serious and heartfelt punches to the gut.

It's very easy to be F2P, compared to other gachas I've played over the past decade. For full disclosure, I've paid only for the battle pass (which is cheap and easy to complete in a fraction of the time it's available) and have bought no other packs/currency. You could probably subsist entirely on the shard crates you earn each week if you wanted to never touch the gacha. Other than the Arknights collab E.G.Os, nothing is truly limited-time only which I appreciate a lot! Please do not change that Project Moon, I beg of thee. (As an aside, I also love how diegetic everything is -- the gacha is real in-world and the UI is themed around Dante's office and PDA.)

The only lasting complaints I have are about the combat. Vertical difficulty walls are very real; boss fights at the end of Cantos can reach up to an hour and a half, and you can't save and quit partway through. That's all standard for Project Moon games (or so I have been told) but doesn't mean I like it. Nonetheless, I persevered through all of the currently-available content.
The in-game tutorial is still not great (despite updates), so I recommend either having a friend walk you through the combat system or watching a YouTube tutorial. Combat is fairly simple once you understand how it actually works. Be prepared to read a lot of skill and passive descriptions.
I've seen people say Mirror Dungeons are boring, but I thoroughly enjoyed the Extreme mode they added to it this season and thought it was a fun challenge! I don't mind waiting for new story content, and am content to skip through my dailies and do my MD runs whenever I feel like it. If you want to play all the time you will probably get bored, but I prefer the relaxed pace.

Overall: thumbs up and 4/5 stars, how did I manage to get 400 hours of playtime in this game already, please send help I'm obsessed. Can't wait for Canto 9!! (Heart heart star star, truly ideal, LIMBUSSSS COMPANYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY)

Limbus Company is a turn-based Gacha single player rpg in which you take the role of manager as you lead the twelve “sinners”/“prisoners” in battle. 

The game is set in Project Moons dark fantasy setting of “The City”, a country sized capitalist dystopian city where the poor have to fight to survive and the rich live carefree lives. 

The twelve sinners are based on popular characters from literature, such as Don Quixote, The Odyssey and Moby Dick. Their stories are retold through the lens of the city in the games main story. 

The gacha element ties into the combat system as sinners equip alternate reality versions of themselves in order to fight monsters and other foes. 

It’s the kinda game that you don’t have to pay any money to enjoy, and I would recommend not spending any money until you’re sure you like it. I didn’t really get hooked until I was a decent way into the story and got attached to the characters. Also most of my playtime is on mobile.

Limbus Company is the third installment in the project moon game trilogy and the most recent release (in terms of PM timeline and game/web comic releases). It's predecessors (Lobotomy Corporation: A roguelike monster-managment simulation) and Library Of Ruina (A turn based RPG taking place years after the ending of Lob Corp and expands on the world we see the game take place in) are great plays, just like Limbus is. LoR did a great job at giving us some of the world but Limbus company takes it many strides further and takes us all around the city and also gives us call backs to other characters and events in previous titles (and comics). While it is the easiest of the three titles, Limbus Company is a game that brings characters based on real life books and converts them to sinners working under a contract for Limbus Comany (the in-game company). The combat isn't hard to understand but where this game strives IS the story of Limbus. As stated before, it takes us all around the city and gives us (no so accurate) retellings of these sinners' stories. My favorite is definitely Heathcliff (Wuthering Heights By Emily Brontë) and his Canto/Chapter in the game. The character interactions are amazing and show the development of these characters. The different story points also have made me cry so many times. I would definitely recommend this game to any story lovers.

I've now played this game for a few months and have caught up with all the relevant content in the game (all cantos and intervallos), so I think I have a pretty good idea of what the game is like. Prepare for a lengthy and in-depth (spoiler-free) review.

Note: I have not played Lobotomy Corporation or Library of Ruina. The only Project Moon game I have played is Limbus Company.

GACHA:

You may have heard people say that the gacha in Limbus is really good and generous. It is not. The gacha mechanic itself is quite horrible. The rate up is similar to most modern gachas these days (that is to say, an absolute horrid 50/50 chance to get the featured units), but unlike most gachas, Limbus very commonly has two or more featured units at once, meaning that your chances of getting the specific unit you'd like is actually 25%! If you're unlucky like me, the experience can be genuinely depressing as the game can simply refuse to give you any rate-up unit over and over again.

The good news? 

You don't have to rely on gacha to get the units you want. With the shard/ego crate system, you can basically just redeem the card you want by using the remnants of your failed pulls (each dupe gives shards of a certain character- you can also get them via crates which can be obtained during events etc.)

Obviously, this did not help AT ALL during the Arknights collab (which is why I am particularly salty at the game - 300 pulls not netting me a single rate-up EGO), but if you're joining NOW, you won't have a chance to get them anyways, so all obtainable units will be able to be 'sharded'. 

The shards are relatively easy to get, which I appreciate because Limbus will absolutely 100% lock you behind relevant content if you do not have good enough units to clear it. 

Which leads us to...

GAMEPLAY:

The gameplay is basically a fancy version of a coin toss. Win the coin toss = good. Lose the coin toss = bad. Each unit has different ways of increasing their chance to win the coin toss. But sometimes you're just doomed.

That is to say, this game can be tough, but it, in my experience, is not challenging in any meaningful way. If you come here expecting really in-depth and interesting turn-based gameplay, you should probably look somewhere else. However, as someone who absolutely loathes Honkai Star Rail for basically being Button Clicker Simulator, I find Limbus gameplay to be passably enjoyable.

Note that there is no AUTO botton, and the game does NOT save your progress in a fight. If your game happens to crash, your progress is GONE. 

MAIN STORY/CHARACTERS:

The main story chapters by themselves, in a vacuum, are good. 

They're good. They're solid, well-written and emotional. Other people have praised the story to death, and I half-agree with them, and so while I maintain that the story is good, I'll offer some flaws for your consideration as well.

1) Characters do very little to contribute in stories that are not their own.

In Limbus, each story ("canto") is centered around a certain character. This is where most, if not all, their character development lies. However, outside of their own canto, characters take action or offer input that could meaningfully affect the story (or at least the central character), with their relevance mostly being reduced to bit parts, or even NPCs. 

After their canto is done, you are basically begging for scraps for even a sliver of character development for your new favorite character. This means that if you were hoping to see our main characters regularly lifting each other up or helping their colleagues using the new wisdom they've gained from going through their own character arc, then you should probably forget that. The ONLY exception to this that seems to regular assert himself as a proper character in a story is Sinclair, who is the youngest and most immature character of the group, meaning the story treats him as though he still has room to grow. 

This also sucks because if you happen to like any character who hasn't had their canto yet, you basically have to play the waiting game before your favorite PNG can turn into an actual, fully-realised character. This game has been out for years, and yet I do not know more than one or two meaningful things about half the cast. While I understand that most of their character development must be saved for their own canto, there is nothing stopping these characters from offering meaningful insights into the experience of their peers. 

2) The game can be unclear

Limbus likes to keep its mystery aspect fairly strong, but it sometimes results in them under-explaining certain elements. In Canto 4, a group of individuals is introduced, but we are not given details of how many people are in the group, nor even all their names. Later on, new members of that group are introduced, and I was left confused, wondering if I had missed something in the flashback that happened in the previous story. I had not. they simply just decided to drop in an extremely important, relevant new character that was connected to a previous character without a single drop of foreshadowing. 

It also likes dropping terminology from its other games inside the story with no real explanation. You ARE given what's basically a dictionary summarizing what each terms mean, however it can still take you out of the story/break immersion as you start wondering what on earth the characters are talking about now. Concepts are always introduced immediately before they start being used in-story and thus there is no room to breathe or properly take time to comprehend the new information that has been given to you.

However, take note that despite these flaws, I do genuinely enjoy the story of Limbus Company. However, these flaws are also much too great for me to ignore, and actively hinder my enjoyment.

Also, side note, but I genuinely do not like the translation for Canto 4. It is extremely clunky and sometimes lacks flow that might have been present in the original Korean text. It actively made me start to dislike the story as I struggled to comprehend what on earth anyone was saying. However, the canto does end strongly and this issue nas never appeared in any canto since. 


GACHA CARD STORIES:

Each gacha card, or 'identity', comes with its own small story about a mirror world, also known as an Alternate Universe. As someone who loves alternate universes and loves card-collecting gacha games (where the whole point is that each card possesses its own mini story), I do have some Thoughts on it.

First, I want to point out that none of the gacha cards feature the characters before, during or after their character arcs in the main story. This is a huge point of frustration for me, as we are unable to PLAY as them as they are in the current story, but this is just a personal wish of mine and not something I hold against the writers.

Okay, here we go. I'm running out of space, so lets blitz.

1) There is a huge gap in story quality and length between each card

Some stories offer an in-depth and introspective look at an alternate possibility for a character. Others just drop the premise into your lap, tease you a bit, and leave. Which Is An Issue, because the purpose of card-collecting stories is to let you learn more about the character outside of the main story, and that can't very well happen if the story provides absolutely 0 new character insight because the story is 3~5 minutes long and is more focused on making charas look badass!

2) Cards sometimes struggle to reconcile with the base character

Some IDs feel less like a proper alternate possibility for a character and more like the character LARPing, as they are so entirely disconnected from their base self. This is super obvious in some Sinclair stories, which sucks for me. 

I'm running out of space.

Even with the infamous community it has garnered, Project Moon continues to put incredible amounts of love into their work. The characters are well-defined, the story is never afraid to shy from commentary on the human experience, and overall the game retains the challenge that drew me into their previous titles, although much of the main story is easier for a casual audience.

It is refreshing seeing a title in the gacha format that not only makes nearly every unit viable, but also allows players to reasonably grind for every identity outside of the limited time Walpurgisnacht IDs (which are still available to shard during the next Walpurgis) and a limited time collaboration event (which contained non-meta defining E.G.O.).

There is also the appeal of extensive literary references hidden within each of the main cast members. Their in-game character arcs usually play out as a twisted parallel to their book counterparts, and reading their original story is a very rewarding experience to explore what goes differently in the world of the City.

If you're interested in the plot and various multimedia related to this game (including webcomic/novel formats), consider diving into the lore and watching videos about the previous games. You can also play them yourself if you don't mind the difficulty.

Limbus Company is one of those games that completely exceeded my expectations. It blends stylish presentation, sharp writing, and strategic turn-based combat into a uniquely polished experience. The atmosphere is striking—dark, surreal, and full of personality—and each Canto (or chapter) pulls you deeper into its unsettling world.

The story is one of the game’s strongest points. Every Canto builds on the last, introducing new characters, locations, and emotional gut punches. They feel like self-contained arcs that still feed into a bigger, overarching narrative. Whether you're traveling through a strange city, uncovering someone's regrets, or watching the crew of Sinners spiral in their own ways, each Canto is memorable and hits with that signature ProjectMoon flavor.

Combat looks simple at first glance but becomes incredibly engaging once you start experimenting with Identities, passives, and resonance mechanics. When a turn lines up just right and all your clashes hit perfectly, it’s incredibly satisfying. The music and voice acting elevate every moment, and the presentation in battles and story segments is consistently top-tier.

For a free-to-play game, it’s also surprisingly fair. Progress feels steady without requiring spending, and the game rewards good strategy more than raw stats.

If you enjoy deep storytelling, turn-based combat with nuance, or anything connected to ProjectMoon’s universe, Limbus Company is absolutely worth jumping into. Stylish, weird, emotional, and full of substance.

Verdict: A standout experience with some of the best chapter-based storytelling on Steam. Highly recommended.

My friend jaidon greaves used to hate on it, until he turned to the dark side Limbus Company isn’t just bad—it’s the kind of bad that feels intentional, like the developers were conducting a psychological experiment to test how long someone can stare at a loading screen before losing their will to live.

The story? Imagine someone shredded a philosophy textbook, fed it to a blender, poured in some dictionary entries, hit “purée,” and then told you to emotionally connect with it. That’s Limbus Company’s narrative experience.

And the progression… I hope you enjoy grinding, because this game treats your time like it’s disposable. The resource economy feels like it was balanced by a committee of sleep-deprived pigeons.

In conclusion, Limbus Company is the kind of game that makes you question your life choices, your hobbies, and possibly your eyesight. It’s stylish, sure—but so is a garbage fire from a distance.

I've been a Project Moon supporter for a long time. I bought Lobotomy Corporation back in 2019 when it still had an incomprehensible EN translation, and before Library of Ruina was even a thing. I have been immersed in PM's world, lore, and setting for years. I have read Leviathan and Distortion Detective multiple times over and loved both of them to pieces.

When Project Moon announced that Limbus Company was going to be a gacha game, I immediately felt that the future of the franchise would be tenuous. But I had faith in the Director's word, and his vision that he'd been sharing with us for years already. The gameplay was shallow and disappointing, but we were getting more Project Moon writing and lore, so it was serviceable for a time. The gacha was only in service of getting other games shipped anyways, supposedly. Distortion Detective was even cancelled because Project Moon claimed to have huge plans for it, so surely that's going to be a huge priority with all the gacha money the team will have to work with... right?

Well, Project Moon have very thoroughly proven otherwise. They announced on an anniversary event that they'd be shuttering all non-Limbus projects indefinitely (utterly insane thing to do by the way, such incredible balls to spit in the face of all their old guard fans during a supposed celebration), they've slowly made the F2P experience more hostile by implementing a week waiting period on sharding to induce FOMO while increasing the rate of ID release to bleed players dry on shard boxes, and now they've implemented a truly limited collab event that can take up to 600 (SIX HUNDRED) pulls for players to get all the items. This is made much worse by the fact that the E.G.O pool is heavily diluted if you don't own all of the older ones already on top of having the worst rates in the game — I cannot imagine how horrific the pulling experience must be for newer players that still have a lot of standard E.G.O in their pool through no fault of their own, making the collab's gacha content even more difficult to attain.

But even worse than all that is the consequences this collab has on the actual core of the game! Project Moon choosing to sacrifice an entire Intervallo story arc, which probably would've been tremendously important for the development of a main character and built up their backstory going into their major story arc? What are we even doing? How can you choose to abandon content that belongs in the CORE GAME just to have an indulgent, masturbatory collab with another game just because the Director really likes it? If it's that easy to cloud his vision, then why should I have any faith in it moving forward? And that's just the tip of the iceberg — there's even more content being lost to facilitate this highly temporary, dubiously canon collab/fanfiction event that will be permanently removed from the game in four weeks. Great allocation of resources. I'm so glad that a ton of content needed to be cut to produce this transient, tasteless waste.

If you're curious about this game because you've been influenced by diehard secondary fans of the franchise going crazy about it on Roblox or underage Twitter, which is now Project Moon's main western fanbase, I would very much encourage you to go play and enjoy Lobotomy Corporation and Library of Ruina instead. The writing in those games and the subsequent novels are what made Project Moon truly soar. While Limbus Company has some high highs in its writing, the vast majority of its story content is a complete disappointment in comparison to the prior two games. Meaningless filler and empty prose, flanderized caricatures instead of characters (Did you know Rodion likes eating? The game will be sure to tell you every other time she speaks), terrible plot contrivances, and horrendous pacing/story restrictions due to the live service model's developmental time restraints. The tone between everything Project Moon has produced before Limbus and Limbus Company itself is like night and day, two entirely different universes, and it sucks. It's really disappointing.

On top of all of this, despite the fact that the game has been in service for nearly three years now, the management of the game is utterly atrocious. The game is constantly experiencing delays and gaps in content because the Director refuses to invest in company growth, due to the fact that he wouldn't be able to 'control' his employees as thoroughly. The game is riddled with bugs almost every patch, both big and small. There have been multiple instances of huge drama stemming from the incompetent and poor management of the project. Project Moon seem to want to be able to pull their "small indie developer" card and garner sympathy by having the Director cry on stream about how mentally ill and stressed it would make him to actually improve the production of the game, but also reap the rewards of the gacha model by raking in boatloads of cash to blow on superfluous things that the Director wants for vanity purposes, like an anime or this collab.

Here's to another ten years of Limbus Company and nothing else. No city builder, no action game, no Distortion Detective, nothing. Because no matter how bad this game gets, its adherents will pronounce it to be "PEAK" and shatter spending records every time a new FOMO banner rolls out. It's painfully ironic to see the Director become the very definition of corporate greed that he's spent his entire career up until now criticizing with this very franchise. And if you read this and your first reaction is to feel offended, or feel that you need to defend Project Moon's transparently profit-driven decisions, then congratulations! You've developed a parasocial relationship with a businessman that openly says he just wants your money. Project Moon is not your friend and they will continue to fleece you dry if you let them. I will continue to play this game because I am still interested enough in where the story is going to see it to its conclusion, but my interest, faith, and patience for Project Moon as a studio has dried up completely. I will not spend another cent on this game, and I encourage you to do the same if you're reading this.
